journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: A calculation method of joint forces for a suspension considering nonlinear elasticity of bushings

article-meta.aff: 1School of Technology, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing, People’s Republic of China
2School of Mechanical and Automotive Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Liang Tang, School of Technology, Beijing Forestry University, Beijing 10083, People’s Republic of China. Email: tang-l04@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn

abstract.p: The forces and/or moments applied to a ball joint and a bushing in one suspension are important loads for the design or fatigue tests of control arms, trailing bars and steering knuckles. Taking a double wishbone suspension as one studying example, a modeling and calculation method for obtaining the forces applied to the ball joints and the bushings, and moments applied to the bushings are proposed and developed in this article. In modeling of a suspension, a bushing is modeled with three translational stiffness and three torsional stiffness along and around three orthogonal axes. The force (moment) versus displacement (angle) along (around) one axis is nonlinear and is simplified as piecewise linear at five sections. The joint forces and moments for ball joints and bushings of a double wishbone suspension system are calculated with the proposed method in this article, and compared with that obtained using two conventional methods (method I and method II) when a vehicle runs in typical and extreme driving conditions. Conventional method I simplifies the connections between the control arm and body as rigid link. Conventional method II assumes that the control arm links with the body using bushings, in which the bushings are modeled as three linear stiffness along three orthogonal axes. The calculation and comparison demonstrate that the bushing nonlinear and rotational stiffness must be modeled for precise calculation of ball joint force and moments, especially when a vehicle runs in extreme driving conditions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A control arm is an important component for transferring load and controlling the suspension motion when a vehicle runs in typical and extreme driving conditions. Every vehicle manufacture divides driving conditions into three cases: typical, extreme and abuse cases. Extreme driving condition of a vehicle is defined as a vehicle running cases that seldom happens. The loads applied to a component when a vehicle runs in extreme cases are usually used for strength test, while the loads of typical cases are used for fatigue test.

Usually, a control arm connects to car body using bushings, and connects to wheel knuckle using ball joint. When a vehicle is on motion, loads applied at the tire contact patch will be transferred to the wheel knuckle, the ball joint, the control arm, bushings, and finally to the car body. Under the loads, the bushings and springs of a suspension will deform, resulting in the translational and rotational movement of a control arm.

Finite element analysis (FEA) and fatigue test are commonly procedures for the design and experimental validation for a component of a suspension.1–4 No matter what procedure is to be used, forces applied to a ball joint, and forces and moments applied to a bushing are important loads and must be determined firstly.

To determine the forces and moments of a suspension in design phase, methods for a suspension modeling and joint forces/moments calculation must be established. Modeling and calculating methods proposed in previous literatures can be divided into the following three categories. The first method is to model a full vehicle model based on multi-body dynamics theory, then calculate joint forces and moments for a given vehicle driving condition.5,6 In this method, the model is more close to a real vehicle, but some parameters, such as center of gravity and moment of inertia for each component are needed, which is difficult to obtain in the initial design stage. The second method is to model only a suspension system, and the dynamic forces measured from a vehicle test are applied to wheel spindle.7 Using this method, the dynamic joint forces and moments can be calculated, while the dynamic input forces and moments must be measured from experiments. The third method is to model only a suspension using quasi-static method,8–12 and the input forces and moments applied to the contact point between tire and ground can be calculated corresponding to the vehicle driving conditions that are well defined in the car company’s load specification. In this article, the third method is adopted to calculate the joint forces and moments.

In the dynamic analysis of a vehicle or a suspension system, the bushing is usually modeled as a nonlinear viscoelastic element,13,14 while in kinematic and static (or quasi-static) analysis, the bushing is modeled as an element with nonlinear force versus displacement relation along and around three orthogonal axes.8–12

To determine the joint forces and moments of a suspension in design phase is an important task, and the modeling and calculating methods proposed in many researches are based on the third method. Micheal et al.8 make an assumption that the connections between the control arm and body is rigid link using ball joints and inline joint primitive constraint, and linear equilibrium static equations are established to calculate the joint forces and moments. Shu et al.9 present a model for calculating joint forces and moments of a McPherson suspension assuming that the control arm connects with the body using bushings, and the elasticity of bushings is modeled as three linear stiffness along three orthogonal axes, and a displacement matrix method is used to calculate the forces and moments. Knapczyk and Dzierzek10 present a vector algebraic method for the displacement and force analysis of a five-road suspension. The bushing is also simplified as three linear spring along each axis of its LCS as it did in Suh9 and Rocca and Russo.12

However, this article presents a more complex and a sophisticated model for calculating joint forces and moments of a suspension. Enhancements of this article to already published papers8–12 are that the bushing in a suspension is modeled with three translational stiffness and three torsional stiffness along or around three orthogonal axes. The force (moment) versus displacement (angle) along (around) one axis is nonlinear and simplified as piecewise linear at five section. The equilibrium equation for each rigid body is established, and the sum of each equilibrium equation and displacement constraint equation constitute the equilibrium equations of a suspension. Since the force (moment) versus displacement (angle) of a bushing along (around) one axis is nonlinear, the equilibrium equation for a suspension is also nonlinear. An iterative algorithm is developed for obtaining joint force and moment of a suspension in this article, which is relative concise in form and thus convenient for programming, providing a very efficient and accurate algorithm.

Taking a double wishbone suspension as one studying example, the joint forces for ball joint and bushing, and moments for bushings are calculated with the proposed method in this article, and compared with that obtained using two conventional methods (method I and method II) when a vehicle runs in some typical and extreme loads. Conventional method I simplifies the connections between the control arm and body as rigid link.8 Conventional method II assumes that the control arm links with the body using bushings, in which the bushings are simplified as three linear stiffness along three orthogonal axes.9,10,12 The calculation and comparison demonstrate that the bushing nonlinear and rotational stiffness must be modeled for precision calculation of ball joint force and moments if a suspension undergo some extreme loads. The joint forces and moments obtained from the proposed modeling and iteration method in this article can be used as input loads for the design and fatigue test of bushings, control arms, trailing bars and steering knuckles.

sec.title: Modeling of a suspension and sketch of calculation method for joint loads
Modeling of a suspension system
sec.p:
A double wishbone suspension system is taken as an example to analyze the forces and moments at each of the ball joints and bushings. The configuration of a double wishbone suspension is shown in Figure 1. It consists of a wheel knuckle, two control arms (upper control arm and lower control arm), a spring, a shock absorber and a tie rod. Figure 1.
The configuration of a double wishbone suspension system.
A, B: the front and rear bushing on the upper control arm; E, F: the front and rear bushing on the lower control arm; D, G: the ball joints between control arms and wheel knuckle; I, C: the ball joints on the shock absorber; J, H: the ball joints on the tie rod; K: a rigid connection point between wheel and knuckle; L: the wheel center; P: the tire contact patch.

Four bushings, bushing A and B, and bushing E and F, connect the upper and lower control arms to a car body, respectively. The ball joint D and G connect the wheel knuckle with upper and lower control arm, respectively. The ball joint H and J connect the tie road with wheel knuckle and body, respectively. Two ends of the helical spring and the shock absorber are mounted between the upper control arm and car body with ball joint C and ball joint I, respectively.

A right-hand global coordinate system (GCS), og-xgygzg, is built to describe the location of the joints, where the origin of the GCS locates at the C.G. of a car in its static equilibrium. The three orthogonal coordinate axes are defined as the xg and the yg axes parallel to the horizontal plane, the zg axis normal to the plane, and the positive direction of xg axis points to the rear of the car. Also one local coordinate system (LCS), os–usvsws (s represents bushing A, B, E or F) is built for each bushing, where the origin locates at the center of the bushing, and the three orthogonal coordinate axes are expressed by us, vs and ws, respectively.

sec.title: Modeling of a bushing
sec.p:
The bushings of a suspension absorb vibrations and decrease the transmissibility of the road irregularities.13 Usually a bushing is modeled as three-dimensional linear springs in its LCS for calculation of force and moment of a ball joint and bushing.9,10,12 In this article, a bushing is modeled as three-dimensional springs with both translational stiffness and rotational stiffness along and around each axis of its LCS, and is shown in Figure 2. Translational stiffness along each axis of a bushing LCS are represented by ktu, ktv and ktw, respectively. Rotational stiffness around each axis of a bushing LCS are represented by kru, krv and krw, respectively. Figure 2.
A bushing model.

The relation between force (or torque) and displacement (or angle) for a bushing in one direction of its LCS is usually nonlinear and can be simplified as piecewise linear at five ranges as in our previous studies for modeling an engine mount.15 Figure 3 shows the piecewise linearity at five ranges. The force (or torque) versus displacement (or angle) relation in Figure 3 is described as (1)F=kx+Δ where k and Δ are stiffness (translational or rotational) and correction term respectively, and their values can be obtained with formulae in Table 1 when displacement, x, is determined. Figure 3.
Force versus displacement relation of a bushing in one direction of its LCS. Table 1.
Values for k and Δ.
x range K Δ
Range 1 (−∞, a] k1 −k1a + k2(a − b) + k3b
Range 2 (a, b] k2 −k2b + k3b
Range 3 (b, c] k3 0
Range 4 (c, d] k4 k3c − k4c
Range 5 (d, +∞) k5 k3c − k4c + k4d − k5d

sec.title: Calculation of new location for a point in a rigid body
sec.p: When the rigid body undergoes both rotation and translation simultaneously, the new coordinate of point M, {M*}, can be obtained by subtracting equation (3) from equation (2), and is expressed as (4){M*}=[X(α)][Y(β)][Z(γ)]{{M0}-{N0}}+{N*}

It is seen from equation (4) that in calculation of the new coordinate of point M, the new coordinate of point N is chosen as a reference point. If the suspension undergoes a motion under one load acting on the tire, the new location for a ball joint in suspensions can be found using equation (4) if the initial position of each ball joint, the new position of the reference joint and the rotation angles of the rigid body are known.

sec.title: Sketch of calculation method for joint forces and moments
sec.p: If a quasi-static load, {FPg}, is applied to the contact patch (P) between the tire and the ground for one case of vehicle running, the configuration of the suspension will be changed since there are many elastic elements in the suspension, such as bushings and springs. From the new and the initial location for a busing and a spring, the displacement of the bushing and the spring then can be calculated. From the calculated displacement and the stiffness of bushings and springs, the reaction forces of bushing and spring to control arms can be obtained.

Each rigid body in a suspension will reach to its static equilibrium under the forces and moments from bushings and springs, external forces and internal forces at each ball joints. The static equilibrium equation of a suspension is the sum of the equilibrium equation for each rigid body. The forces and moments for a ball joint and a bushing, and the new configuration of a suspension are then determined by solving the static equilibrium equation of a suspension.

sec.title: Equilibrium equations of a suspension system
Calculation of new location of ball joints
sec.p: If an external load, {FPg}, is applied to a patch between the tire and the ground, the control arms, then the wheel knuckle and tie rod will move to a new position due to the elastic deformation of bushings and springs in a suspension, and a new static equilibrium is then achieved.
If ball joint D is chosen as the reference point, and the new locations of other ball joints in this load can then be calculated using equation (4).

sec.title: (1) Calculation of new location of ball joints on control arms
sec.p: Using equation (4), the new location of ball joint A, B and C, {A*}, {B*} and {C*}, on the upper control arm in GCS can be estimated as (5){{A*}{B*}{C*}}=[[R(αu,βu,γu)],0,00,[R(αu,βu,γu)],00,0,[R(αu,βu,γu)]]{{{A0}-{D0}}{{B0}-{D0}}{{C0}-{D0}}} +{{D*}{D*}{D*}} where 0 is the (3 × 3) zero matrix; the {A0}, {B0}, {C0} and {D0} are the initial coordinates of ball joint A, B, C and D, respectively; The {D*} is the new location of ball joint D, and matrix [R(αu,βu,γu)] is a rotation matrix and is expressed as (6)[R(αu,βu,γu)]=[X(αu)][Y(βu)][Z(γu)] where [Z(γu)], [Y(βu)] and [X(αu)] are the (3 × 3) rotation matrices when the upper control arm is rotated by an angle of γu, βu and αu about the z-, y-, x-axis of its rigid coordinate system, respectively.

Using equation (4), the new locations of ball joint E and F, {E*} and {F*}, on the lower control arm in GCS are estimated (7){{E*}{F*}}=[[R(αl,βl,γl)],00,[R(αl,βl,γl)]]{{{E0}-{G0}}{{F0}-{G0}}} +{{G*}{G*}} where {E0}, {F0} and {G0} are the initial position of Joint E, F and G, respectively; {G*} is the new location of ball joint G; and the matrix [R(αl,βl,γl)] is a rotation matrix and is expressed as (8)[R(αl,βl,γl)]=[X(αl)][Y(βl)][Z(γl)] where [Z(γl)], [Y(βl)] and [X(αl)] are the (3 × 3) rotation matrices when the lower control arm is rotated by an angle of γl, βl and αl about the z-, y-, x-axis of its rigid coordinate system, respectively.

sec.title: (2) Calculation of new location of the ball joint and points on the wheel knuckle
sec.p: New positions for ball joints G, H and the point P, {G*}, {H*} and {P*} in GCS are estimated using equation (4) (9){{G*}{H*}{P*}}=[[R(αk,βk,γk)],0,00,[R(αk,βk,γk)],00,0,[R(αk,βk,γk)]]{{{G0}-{D0}}{{H0}-{D0}}{{P0}-{D0}}} +{{D*}{D*}{D*}} where {H0} and {P0} are the initial position of Point H and P respectively; and the matrix [R(αk,βk,γk)] is expressed as (10)[R(αk,βk,γk)]=[X(αk)][Y(βk)][Z(γk)] where [Z(γk)], [Y(βk)] and [X(αk)] are the (3 × 3) rotation matrices when the wheel knuckle is rotated by an angle of γk, βk and αk about the z-, y-, x-axis of its rigid coordinate system, respectively.

According to equations (5), (7) and (9), all the new locations for each ball joint and bushing can be acquired if an external force is applied to a suspension. The displacements of a bushing and spring can then be estimated easily.

sec.title: Equilibrium equation of the control arms
(1) Forces and moments applied to the bushings
sec.p: The {ΔS0g} and {ΔφS0g} in equation (11) are the initial translational displacements and rotational angles of bushing s in GCS under the weight of the car respectively, an iterative algorithm is used to determine the initial displacements of the bushings and is described in the section ‘Solution of equations.’

The forces and moments applied to bushing s in GCS due to the displacements of a bushing are (12){{FSg}{MSg}}=[[KStg],00,[KSrg]]{QSg}+[[RS]T,00,[RS]T]{ΔSl} where {FSg} and {MSg} are the (3 × 1) force vector and torque vector, respectively; and (13)[KStg]=[RS]T[KStl][RS] (14)[KSrg]=[RS]T[KSrl][RS] are the translational stiffness matrix and rotational stiffness matrix of bushing s in GCS, respectively; [KStl]=diag(kStu,kStv,kStw) and [KSrl]=diag(kSru,kSrv,kSrw) are the translational stiffness matrix and rotational stiffness matrix of bushing s in its LCS respectively; [RS] is the (3 × 3) transformation matrix from GCS to LCS of bushing s. The transformation matrix can be easily formed from the orientation of the bushing with respect to GCS, which can be defined using Euler angles or direction cosines, etc.

The {ΔSl} in equation (12) is the correction vector of bushing s in its LCS and is expressed as (15){Δsl}=(Δstul,Δstvl,Δstwl,Δsrul,Δsrvl,Δsrwl)T where T denotes transpose of a matrix; the values of each component in {ΔSl} for bushing s are correction terms for different force versus displacement relations along or around its LCS.
The values of each component in [KStl], [KSrl] and {ΔSl} can be obtained with the formulae in Table 1 according to the displacements of bushing s in its LCS.

sec.title: (2) Forces and moments applied to a control arm from a bushing
sec.p: According to equation (12), regarding displacements of ball joint D as unknowns, forces and moments applied to the upper control arms in GCS from the reaction forces and moments of the bushing Su (Su can be A or B) are (16){{RFSug}{RMSug}}=[I,0[R~SuD*],I]{-{FSug}-{MSug}} where I is the (3 × 3) unity matrix; the [R~SuD*] in equation (16) is the (3 × 3) skew-symmetric matrix of the position vector for the bushing Su, {RSuD*}, in GCS. That is, if {RSuD*} is given by (17){RSuD*}=xSuDgi→+ySuDgj→+zSuDgk→
Then the skew-symmetric matrix, [R~SuD*], is expressed as (18)[R~SuD*]=[0-zSuDgySuDgzSuDg0-xSuDg-ySuDgxSuDg0] where xSuDg, ySuDg and zSuDg are coordinate components in {RSuD*} in GCS.

sec.title: (3) Equilibrium equation of the control arms
Equilibrium equation of the wheel knuckle
Constraint equation of a suspension system
sec.p: The length of a spring after deformation, its displacement and the initial length satisfy with the following equation (25)LIC*+ΔLIC-LIC=0 where LIC* is the new length of the spring, and LIC is the initial length of the spring. The ΔLIC is the displacement of the spring and is calculated by (26)ΔLIC=(fs2LIC*-fs20LIC)/Kd where fs20 is the initial scale factor of spring force and Kd is the stiffness of spring.

The length of tie rod is unchanged whatever the configuration of a suspension changes, its constraint equations is (27)LJH*-LJH=0 where LJH* and LJH are the length of the tie rod calculated from the coordinates of point J* and H*, and J and H, respectively.

sec.title: Equilibrium equation of a suspension system
sec.p: By combining the equilibrium equation for upper and lower control arms, equations (20) and (22), equilibrium equation for wheel knuckle, equation (23), and the constraint equation for spring and tie rod, the equation for a suspension system is then expressed as (28){{{RFAg}{RMAg}}+{{RFBg}{RMBg}}+{{FCg}{MCg}}+{{FDg}0}{{RFEg}{RMEg}}+{{RFFg}{RMFg}}+{{FGg}0}{{FPg}{MPg}}-{{FDg}{MDg}}-{{FHg}{MHg}}-{{FGg}0}{LIC*+ΔLIC-LICLJH*-LJH}}={0}

sec.title: Solution of equations
sec.p: There are 20 equations in equation (28), and the number of unknown variables is also twenty. The unknown variables are: three coordinates for the new location of Joint D, {D*}=(Dx*,Dy*,Dz*)T; nine rotational angles for control arms and wheel knuckle, (αu,βu,γu)T, (αl,βl,γl)T, (αk,βk,γk)T; three forces applied to ball joint D, {FDg}=(FDxg,FDyg,FDzg)T; three forces applied to ball joint G, {FGg}=(FGxg,FGyg,FGzg)T; two scale factors, fs1, fs2, describing the spring force and reaction force applied to the wheel knuckle from the tie rod.

Equation (28) is nonlinear equation and the quasi Newton iterative algorithm is used to get its solution. For a nonlinear equation, F(x) = 0, where x is unknown variables, the relationship of unknown variables in the (m + 1) iteration and m iteration is (29)xm+1=xm-Am-1F(xm) where (30)Am+1=Am+(zm-Amym)(ym)T ‖ym‖ (31)ym=xm+1-xm (32)zm=F(xm+1)-F(xm) where x is the vector that has n unknown variables; Am is a nonsingular matrix.

In equation (11), the displacement of a bushing under the weight of the car should be calculated firstly to obtain the translational displacements and rotational angles of a bushing in any load case. The displacements of a bushing in its LCS should be in linear range (k3) and the {Δ} in equation (1) should be zero under the weight of the car. An iterative algorithm is used to determine the initial displacements of the bushings, and the steps are described as follows.
Step 1: Assume the displacements of the bushing under the weight of the car in GCS are zero, and take the value as the initial displacements of the bushings used in step 2.

Step 2: Calculate the rotational angles of control arms and wheel knuckle, and the new location of ball joint D by solving nonlinear equation (28) when an external load is applied to the tire contact patch. The new position for bushing A and B, and bushing E and F in GCS are calculated with equations (5) and (7), respectively. The displacement of a bushing in GCS is then calculated with equation (11).
Record the displacement of a bushing calculated in this step, and then take it as the initial displacement for the bushing in step 3.

Step 3: Repeat the calculation in step 2 and then get a newly calculated displacement for the bushing. Check the difference between the displacements obtained in step 2 and step 3, and to see if they are less than a specified value.
If it is yes, output the displacements of the bushing and then stop. The initial displacement of the bushing under the weight of the car is the displacement obtained in step 3.
If it is no, repeat the calculation in step 2 and step 3, and regard the displacement obtained in step 3 as the initial displacement for the bushing used in step 2, and then go to the step 2.
According to step 1, step 2 and step 3, the initial displacements of each bushing under the weight of the car can then be determined.

If an external force is applied to the tire contact patch, the value of the components in the stiffness matrix in equation (28) and the correction vector depend on the magnitude of the external load, an iterative algorithm must be used to determine the displacement of a bushing. The steps are described as follows.

Step 1: Calculate the new location of ball joint D, and the rotational angles of control arms and wheel knuckle in GCS by solving equation (28) when an external load is applied to the tire contact patch, assuming the displacements of each bushing in its LCS are in the linear range.
Step 2: Calculate the new positions of bushing A, B, E and F in GCS using equations (5), (7) and (9).
Step 3: Calculate the displacement of a bushing in GCS using equation (11), and transform the displacements from GCS to LCS of each bushing.
Step 4: Check the displacements of each bushing in its LCS obtained in step 3 to see if they are in the linear range.
If it is yes, output the displacements of each bushing in GCS and then stop.
If it is no, record the ranges where the displacements for a bushing located in its LCS, and then go to the step 5.
Step 5: Constitute the new stiffness matrix and the correction vector of each bushing with the range data recorded in step 4 and the formulae in Table 1.

Step 6: Estimate the new location of ball joint D, and the rotational angles of control arms and wheel knuckle in GCS by solving equation (28). Calculate the new position of a bushing in GCS with equations (5), (7) and (9). Obtain the displacements of each bushing in GCS using equation (11), and transform the displacements from GCS to LCS of each bushing.

Step 7: Check the displacements of each bushing in its LCS obtained in step 6 to see which ranges of the displacements are located, and record the ranges of the displacements for each bushing in its LCS.
If the displacements for each bushing are located at the same range in the two successive steps, output the calculated results and then stop.
Otherwise, regard the calculated displacements for each bushing in this step as the initial displacement, then go to step 6.

In some loads, the iteration procedures stated above may not converge owing to the inappropriate values of stiffness and tuning points. Therefore, an interrupt program should be designed in the program.

sec.title: Application examples
Parameters of a double wishbone suspension system
sec.p:
A double wishbone suspension studied in this article consists of four bushings and is shown in Figure 1. The initial external force corresponding to vehicle weight, {FP0g}, applied to the tire contact patch under the weight of the car is (0,0,4491) N. The locations of each ball joints in GCS are listed in Table 2. Direction angles are used to describe the orientation of a bushing in its LCS with respect to GCS and are listed in Table 3. The static stiffness (translational and rotational) and the coordinates of tuning points for each bushing in three directions of its LCS are listed in Tables 4 and 5, respectively. Table 2.

sec.title: Calculation results
sec.p:
The forces and moments of ball joints and bushings are calculated using three different models for a double wishbone suspension. The characteristics for each model are shown in Table 6. The mode I proposed in Michael and Damian8 simplifies the connections between the control arm and body as rigid link using ball joints and inline joint primitive constrain. The model II presented in Suh,9 Knapczyk and Dzierzek10 and Rocca and Russo12 assumes that the control arm connects with the body using bushings, but the bushings are simplified as three linear stiffness along three orthogonal axes. The model III is proposed in this article, in which a bushing is used to connect control arms and car body, and is modeled with three linear stiffness and three torsional stiffness along and around three orthogonal axes of its LCS. The force (moment) versus displacement (angle) along (around) of one axis is nonlinear and simplified as piecewise linear at five sections. Table 6.
Characteristics of the three models.
Model Characteristics
I The connections between the control arm and body are rigid links using ball joints and inline joint primitive constrain.
II The connections between the control arm and body are bushings, and a bushing is simplified as three linear stiffness along each axis of its LCS.
III The connections between the control arm and body are bushings, and the bushing is modeled with three linear stiffness and three torsional stiffness along and around each axis of its LCS. The force (moment) versus displacement (angle) along (around) one axis is nonlinear and is simplified as piecewise linear at five section.
LCS: local coordinate system.

To find out the differences between the calculated results of joint force and moment using the model III proposed in the article, and two conventional model (model I and II), two typical loads and two extreme loads corresponding to a vehicle driving on typical and extreme conditions applied to the tire contact patch are used as input loads. Also the calculated reaction forces and moments for each bushing are given.

sec.title: (1) Typical loads
sec.p:
The first typical load is a force applied to the tire contact patch in longitudinal (xg) and vertical (zg) directions of GCS simultaneously when the car is braking with an acceleration of 0.35 g under the speed of 15 km/h, where g is the gravitational acceleration. The second typical load is a force applied to the tire contact patch in lateral (yg) and vertical (zg) directions simultaneously when the car is cornering with an acceleration of 0.75 g under the speed of 15 km/h. The two typical loads are listed in Table 7. The calculated forces applied to control arms, and the calculated forces and moments applied to bushings using the three models are listed in Figures 4 to 11, respectively. Figure 4.
Calculated forces applied to upper control arm in GCS under the typical load 1.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 5.
Calculated forces applied to lower control arm in GCS under the typical load 1.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 6.
Calculated forces applied to upper control arm in GCS under the typical load 2.
GCS: global coordinate system. Table 7.
Two typical loads in GCS (N).
Load no. Description Fx Fy Fz
1 0.35 g reverse braking −1885 0 3324
2 0.75 g cornering 0 −2775 5423
GCS: global coordinate system.

From Figures 4 to 7, it is seen that the calculated forces for ball joint D and G in the two control arm using Model I and III are almost the same under the two typical loads. But the calculated forces for points connected with bushings, points A, B, E and F, are much different using model I and model III, especially for the forces in xg direction of GCS, since model I simplifies the connections between the control arm and body as rigid link. In addition, it is seen that the calculated forces using model II and III are almost the same, and this demonstrates that under the two typical loads, the deformation of a bushing is at linear section, and that the model II can be used to calculate the joint forces if a vehicle runs on typical driving conditions. Figure 7.
Calculated forces applied to lower control arm in GCS under the typical load 2.
GCS: global coordinate system.

Figures 9 to 11 show the forces or moments applied to bushings. From Figures 8 and 9, it is seen that the calculated forces for the bushings using model II and III are almost the same in the view point of engineering application under the two typical loads. This demonstrates that the developed method in this article and the method developed in Suh9 and Knapczyk and Dzierzek10 can be used to calculate the forces for a bushing under the two typical loads. However, the bushing moments can only be calculated using model III since a bushing is modeled with both translational and rotational stiffness around each axis of its LCS, and the calculated bushing moments using model III are shown in Figures 10 and 11. Figure 8.
Calculated forces of the bushings in GCS under the typical load 1.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 9.
Calculated forces of the bushings in GCS under the typical load 2.
GCS: global coordinate system.

sec.title: (2) Extreme loads
sec.p:
The first extreme load is a force applied to the tire contact patch in lateral (yg) and vertical (zg) directions of GCS simultaneously when the car hits the kerb with the speed of 10 km/h. The second extreme load is a force applied to the tire contact patch in vertical (zg) directions when the car is braking in pothole case with the speed of 15 km/h. The two extreme loads are listed in Table 8. The calculated joint forces and moments using different models are listed in Figures 12 to 19. Figure 10.
Calculated moments of the bushings on model III in GCS under the typical load 1.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 11.
Calculated moments of the bushings on model III in GCS under the typical load 2.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 12.
Calculated forces applied to upper control arm in GCS under the extreme load 3.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 13.
Calculated forces applied to lower control arm in GCS under the extreme load 3.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 14.
Calculated forces applied to upper control arm in GCS under the extreme load 4.
GCS: global coordinate system. Table 8.
Extreme loads in GCS.
Load no. Description Fx Fy Fz
3 Kerb impact 0 −7590 5364
4 Pothole braking 10,020 0 8650
GCS: global coordinate system.

Figures 12 to 15 show the calculated forces applied to control arms under the two extreme loads. It is seen that under the extreme loads, the calculated forces for ball joint points and points connected with bushings using different models are quite different. This demonstrates that nonlinear elasticity of a bushing and rotational stiffness of a bushing must be considered for estimating the forces for ball joints and bushings if a vehicle is running under extreme driving conditions. Figure 15.
Calculated forces applied to lower control arm in GCS under the extreme load 4.
GCS: global coordinate system.

Figures 16 to 19 show the calculated forces or moments applied to bushings under two extreme loads. It is seen that the calculated forces for the bushings using model II and III are quite different. The moments applied to the bushings, as are shown in Figures 18 and 19, can only be calculated using model III since a bushing is modeled with both translation stiffness and rotational stiffness along and around each axis of its LCS in model III. In addition, the calculated forces using model III are smaller than that using model II, which demonstrates the conclusion in Kang et al.16 that the durability of control arms can be improved by optimizing the stiffness of bushings. Figure 16.
Calculated forces of the bushings in GCS under the extreme load 3.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 17.
Calculated forces of the bushings in GCS under the extreme load 4.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 18.
Calculated moments of the bushings using model III in GCS under the extreme load 3.
GCS: global coordinate system. Figure 19.
Calculated moments of the bushings using model III in GCS under the extreme load 4.
GCS: global coordinate system.

According to the calculation results and comparisons, it is concluded that in calculation of the force and moment for a ball joint and a bushing in a suspension system, the rotational stiffness and nonlinear elasticity of a bushing must be modeled during extreme loads.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
A modeling and calculation method for obtaining the forces applied to the ball joints and the bushings, and moments applied to the bushings is developed. In modeling of a suspension, a bushing is modeled with three linear stiffness and three torsional stiffness along and around three orthogonal axes. The force (moment) versus displacement (angle) along (around) each axis is nonlinear and is simplified as piecewise linear at five section. The equation and solution method for estimating the forces applied to the ball joints and the bushings, and moments applied to the bushings under quasi-static load is developed. The joint forces in a suspension system are calculated with the proposed method in this article and compared with that obtained using two conventional methods when a vehicle runs in some typical and extreme loads. From the calculations, the following conclusions are found:
The calculated forces applied to ball joints and bushings in a suspension system are almost the same under the typical loads if a bushing is simplified as three linear spring alone with three orthogonal axis.
When an extreme load is applied to the suspension, the forces applied to ball joints and bushings are quite different using different bushing models and calculation methods. Also, the forces calculated by the proposed method in this article are smaller than that obtained by the conventional method proposed in Suh,9 Knapczyk and Dzierzek10 and Rocca and Russo.12 So it is concluded that if one want to get the joint force and moment accurately, the bushings can not be modeled as rigid links or simplified only as three linear stiffness along three orthogonal axes.
The proposed bushing model can model the comprehensive characteristics of a bushing elasticity. An iterative algorithm developed in this article for solving the joint force and moment of a suspension is relative concise in form and convenient for programming, providing a very efficient and accurate algorithm.
The joint loads and moments obtained from the calculation are used as loads for a testing and FEA of control arms and bushing in a small car, and the real vehicle tested data validates that loads corrected with a vehicle driving conditions.
The joint forces and moments obtained from the proposed model and method in this article can be used as input loads for the design and fatigue test of bushings, control arms, trailing bars and steering knuckles.

sec.p: The authors gratefully acknowledge the financial support of Science Creation Project of Beijing Forestry University (Funding no. YX201110), and the Natural Science Foundation of China (Project nos 50975091 and 51275175).
